newsitem.title: USA: Proxim says business trends on track.
newsitem.headline: Proxim says business trends on track.

text.p: Proxim Inc, which Friday terminated a $400 million merger with DSP Communications Inc, said earnings and business trends are on track.
Proxim chief executive officer David King said the deal was mutually terminated due to declines in the firms' shares.
King said, adding, "We moved to terminate it fast so it would not become a distraction. Trends in our business remain very strong," he said.
"I don't believe there will be any out-of-pocket expenses to Proxim sharesholders," King said, referring to the DSP arrangement.

Of the estimated $5 million total merger-related costs and expenses incurred by DSP, about $3.45 million will be paid to Proxim. The total $5 million will be charged to DSP's general and administrative expenses during the current quarter.
"The majority of our fees and expenses will be covered by this amount ($3.45 million)," King said.
The proposed merger was first announced October 29, and the news sent DSP stock down $17 a share.

That day, King said he expected Proxim to meet Wall Street fourth quarter estimates of $0.15 a share. On Friday, he said Proxim remains on track. The proposed deal and its termination did not affect operations during the fourth quarter, he said.
